Brief Hospital Course:
___ with h/o Type 1 Diabetes admitted with nausea/vomiting x3 
days found to have DKA.

# DKA:  likely secondary to stopping long-acting insulin after 
developing gastroenteritis.  Patient reported limited PO intake 
x3 days and was severely dehydrated on exam. Initial labs showed 
anion-gap metabolic acidosis, hyperglycemia, and ketones in 
urine.  Patient was given IV fluids and started on insulin drip 
and his electrolytes were closely monitored.  Anion gap closed 
and patient's nausea/vomiting resolved.  Patient was 
subsequently started on his home lantus and was tolerating meals 
on day of discharge.  Patient's A1c was 6.6%.  He was seen by 
___ team who felt patient was safe to be discharged 
on home regimen of lantus/novolog and was given information and 
encouraged to follow up with ___ for continued management of 
his diabetes while he lives in ___ (from ___, living in 
___ as student).

___.  No diarrhea, and lack of sick contacts, thus 
norovirus is less likely.  N/v resolved with treatment of his 
DKA as above (IVF + insulin gtt).

# Leukocytosis: likely stress response in setting of DKA.  CXR 
and U/A negative.  Improved with treatment of his DKA as noted 
above.

Brief Hospital Course:
#. Rhythm: Pt presents with symptoms of palpitations & 
lightheadedness for ___ days and was newly diagnosed with 
atrial fibrillation with RVR in 150s. The etiology of onset 
remains unclear, TSH was normal & CTA was negative for PE.  Pt 
was treated with IV & po metoprolol in the ED with modest effect 
on rate control (RVR 120-140s) Upon arrival to the floor, pt was 
treated with heparin gtt, IV & po diltiazem. Pt was noted to 
have some intermittent Atrial Fib & Atrial flutter overnight, 
then he spontaneously converted to NSR at 6am and remained in 
sinus rhythm with a HR in 50-60s throughout the day. Pt was 
given ___ monitor to watch for recurrent atrial 
fibrillation. Pt was clinically euvolemic and denied any 
symptoms of CHF on admission.  Pt appeared to have tolerated the 
RVR well and was recommended to get a follow up TTE as an 
outpatient. Pt has CHADs score of 2 and will benefit from 
anticoagulation. Pt was transitioned to Diltiazem SR 180mg and 
discharged with Lovenox ___ sc BID and Warfarin 5mg qhs with a 
plan for INR follow up in 4 days. Pt was instructed to monitor 
for recurrent symptoms of palpitations or lightheadedness and 
return to the ER if symptomatic.  Pt was scheduled to see Dr. 
___ in follow up on ___.
.  
#. CAD: Pt has no known history of CAD & presented with new 
onset Atrial fib with RVR. CK was noted to be mildly elevated 
but the MB fraction & troponins were normal. There were some 
non-specific ST-T waves changes noted when pt was in Atrial Fib 
with RVR that may have been due to rate related demand ischemia. 
 However, pt remained  chest pain free in house and ruled out 
with two sets of neg cardiac enzymes. Pt was continued on ASA 
81mg. Given that he is likely diabetic, he may benefit from the 
addition of a statin to get his LDL down to 70.  Lipid panel 
currently reveals an LDL of 101 and HDL of 40.
.  
#. Hypertension:  Pt was mildy hypertension of admission. 
However, after he spontaneously converted to NSR, the sbp came 
down to 100s & HR in ___ on the Diltiazem 60mg po QID.  He was 
transitioned to Diltiazem SR 180mg.  Lisinopril was held on 
discharge due to sbp in 100-110 & goal for HR control in the 
short term. However, pt was encouraged to discuss restarting the 
Lisinopril if BP was beginning to rise at his follow up 
appointment of ___.
.
#. Diabetes Mellitus: Pt has a history of insulin resistance 
that he has controlled with diet & weight loss in the past. 
However, pt reports that he has gained back a significant amount 
of weight and was noted to have BS ranging in the 150-200s. 
Nutrition was consulted to provide some diabetic diet educaiton 
and his PCP/NP was notified about the elevated BS. HgbA1c was 
significantly elevated at 7.6 and pt was encouraged to discuss 
this with his PCP and consider the addition of a oral 
hypoglycemic while he continues to work on diet and exercise.

#Hypokalemia - Attributed to thiazide diuretic therapy, although 
a primary mineralocorticoid state could not be exluded, 
particularly in light of concomitant difficult-to-control 
hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. HCTZ was discontinued. 
Potassium and magnesium were repleted to within the normal range 
prior to discharge. Admission EKG and telemetry did not reveal 
any arrhythmia. The patient will continue on potassium 
supplementation for 3 days after discharge, at which time she 
will have serum potassium and magnesium levels rechecked. She 
has PCP ___ scheduled in 10 days. 
.  
#Chest tightness - There was a low likelihood of suspicion for 
ACS given a TIMI score of zero and spontaneous resolution of the 
symptom without recurrence.  Therefore, inpatient evaluation was 
deferred and the patient was instructed to schedule repeat 
stress testing as an outpatient. Ruled out for MI with serial 
cardiac markers.
.  
#Hypertension - The patient had elevated SBP to 180 mmHg on 
admission. HCTZ was discontinued due to concerns for 
hypokalemia. Amlodipine 10 mg daily was started. Lisinopril was 
increased to 10 mg daily. Atenolol was continued at the 
outpatient dose of 25 mg daily. Renal MRA, although a limited 
exam, did not reveal any evidence of fibromuscular dysplasia, 
renal artery stenosis, or adrenal mass. Chest CTA did not reveal 
coarctation. TSH was WNL. BP was 144/78 taken manually in the 
right arm while seated prior to discharge. The patient would 
likely benefit from additional outpatient workup of an 
underlying cause of her hypertension, such as serum 
renin/aldosterone (for a primary mineralocortoid state, 
particularly in light of hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis) 
and urinary VMA (for pheochromocytoma). 
.

sleep medicine recommendations dated ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment: ___ year old ___ speaking gentleman with a 
history of AVR and a recent dx of cecal mass who presents for 
colonoscopy and biopsy, requiring transition from coumadin to 
heparin.
  
# Cecal mass: The patient has a history of a cecal mass that was 
thought to represent strongyloides based on immunological 
studies and an eosinophilia.  He was previously treated with 
ivermectin empirically and responded, with an eosonophil 
differential that fell from 40% to approximately 10%.  However, 
there was concern that the patient's mass may have represented a 
carcinoma, and hence he was scheduled for a repeat colonoscopy 
to definitely evaluate the mass.  Because of his AVR, he was 
admitted for bridging, though he may have not required admission 
given that his valve is aortic as opposed to mitral, and because 
he has few risk factors, other than his valve, for 
thromboembolism.  The colonoscopy was performed without 
complications and the patient was found to have complete 
resolution of the mass--it was completely absent.  Biopsies were 
taken nonetheless.  The patient was empirically treated with 
another two week course of ivermectin because his eosinophil 
differential was still elevated.  He will follow up with the GI 
and ID clinics.
  
# AVR:  Patient was bridged with heparin and warfarin was 
restarted after the colonoscopy.  After uncovering AHA/ACC data 
that supports the notion that patients with AVR and few risk 
factors do not need a heparin bridge, the patient was d/c'd on 
just warfarin and not lovenox.  He also was instructed to have 
his coags checked two days after discharge.

# HTN: Patient's BP was well controled with toprol and 
lisinopril

summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were feeling lightheaded. Initially, we thought this might be your heart, however it appears that this was due to the heart failure regimen that you were on being over-aggressive. We gave you some fluids which improved your symptoms, and adjusted your medications slightly in order to stop this from happening again. In particular, we believe that the furosemide (lasix) and metolazone, which are medications that help remove fluid from your body were at too high a dose. In order to stop this from happening again, you should weigh yourself every day in order to help manage your fluid status.
